headline: Upcoming Celestia Upgrade: Hibiscus (V7)
reasoning: The evidence indicates the Hibiscus (V7) upgrade is scheduled for Mainnet in mid-March but has not yet been confirmed as live. The score is 0.7 because the event is scheduled, but no confirmation of execution has been provided.

affected_subtypes.reason: The text states: "CIP-44: Adjust Validator Commission Bounds This CIP increases the maximum validator commission from 25% to 60% and raises the protocol-enforced minimum commission from 10% to 20% to allow validators to operate more sustainable businesses, following the reduction to protocol inflation made in the previous upgrade." This directly modifies parameters affecting monetary flows (validator commission), which is an economic governance right.

The text states: "CIP-45 introduces a forwarding module that enables single-signature cross-chain token transfers via Hyperlane, eliminating the need for users to sign multiple transactions when routing tokens through Celestia to another chain." This enhances the right to relay messages/assets between execution domains (interoperability) by streamlining cross-chain transfers, thus affecting the strength of this right. It also says "CIP-46 introduces a zero-knowledge proof-based Hyperlane Interchain Security Module (x/zkism) that currently uses Groth16 verification to enable trust-minimised cross-chain message verification, replacing reliance on trusted multisig validators." This improves the security of the interoperability relay.

id: celestia_Upcoming Celestia Upgrade: Hibiscus (V7)

headline: ArbOS Dia: Smoother Fees, Higher Throughput
reasoning: The article discusses the benefits and outcomes of the Dia upgrade on Arbitrum One & Nova, indicating it's likely intended for mainnet. While it doesn't explicitly state it's live, the focus on benefits suggests it's either live or very close to being live. The language leans towards 'imminent/certain' rather than 'in progress' or 'speculative'.

affected_subtypes.reason: The text states: "Dia includes pricing updates for Arbitrum One to reduce the severity, frequency, and duration of high L2 gas prices during elevated demand." and "Increasing the default minimum L2 base fee from 0.01 gwei to 0.02 gwei. This helps make spam-style bot activity more expensive, as well as balance and stabilize DAO revenue for the changes from a smoother fee curve." These changes directly impact the fees paid on the network, which alters the monetary flows and economic rules defined in G-01. This impacts ARB because DAO revenue stabilization can influence treasury management.

The text states: "Dia advances two operator-critical improvements that help the network behave more predictably under load and lay the groundwork for higher, more sustainable throughput." and "More efficient block packing. Because a per-transaction limit is introduced, the state transition rules are relaxed to allow the final transaction in a block to use up to the MaxTxGasLimit even if it nudges beyond the prior MaxBlockGasLimit." This implies an improvement in the ability of the network to execute transactions and order them, directly impacting sequencing and execution rights for users and validators. This enhancement strengthens the utility of the ARB token by improving the network's transaction processing capabilities.

id: arbitrum_ArbOS Dia: Smoother Fees, Higher Throughput

headline: Curve: 2025 Year in Review
reasoning: The text explicitly states that FXSwap was added to Curve and pilot markets are being tested, implying it's live on mainnet.

affected_subtypes.reason: The text states 'CRV Emission Rate Gets a Cut - As Programmed Another August, another CRV Emission Rate cut: ~137.4M → ~115.5M CRV/year (≈15.9%) as Epoch 5 starts.' This quote directly shows that the CRV emission rate, which dictates the amount of newly minted CRV tokens distributed each year, was reduced. This directly impacts the 'Inflation Entitlement' of CRV holders, as it alters the amount of newly minted tokens they are entitled to receive.
